title-group.article-title: Hybrid materials based on brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene/chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber blends reinforced by nano and micro silica

author-notes.corresp: Gordana Marković, Tigar, Nikole Pašića 213, Pirot 18300, Serbia Email: gordana1markovic@gmail.com

abstract.p: The effects of different particle size of silica (nano—primary particle size 15 nm and micro—primary particle size 28 μm) on the cure, mechanical, and swelling properties of hybrid materials based on brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene/chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber blend were studied. The enhancement in mechanical properties was supported by the data on the increased content of cross-link density obtained from swelling and stress–strain analyses. The interactions between rubber matrix and filler were investigated by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy with attenuated total reflectance extension and scanning electron microscope. T g of reinforced blend shifted to −26°C and −30°C for nano and micro silica compounds, respectively.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Hybrid materials composed of two or more polymers having different chemical structures are often used, because in that way their optimal properties for specific applications can be obtained. 1
–8 With respect to polymers, the term reinforcement is defined as the increase in properties such as tensile strength (TS), tear resistance, hardness, abrasion resistance, and stiffness. 9 The addition of filler (carbon blacks or silica) in the polymeric matrix is a very common approach used for the optimization of these properties. In recent years, rubber industry has been forced to concentrate more on silica fillers as an alternative to carbons. 2,4 –6,10
–24 From the industrial point of view, preparation of rubber nanocomposites is of great interest for automotive industry because nanocomposites often exhibit significantly improved mechanical, thermal and flammability resistance, gas permeability, and biodegradability. 10 The superior properties of nanocomposites are attributed to the high aspect ratio of the inorganic layers, giving rise to a high degree of polymer–filler surface interactions. Different types of structure can be identified depending on the interactions between the polymer and nanoparticles. Achieving the desired structure is a scientific problem with numerous technological implications because it is the structure that controls the final properties of micro- or nanocomposites. 11
–18 The introduction of chlorine and sulfur dioxide into the polyethylene molecule destroys the crystalline, thereby changing the thermoplastic material into an amorphous polymer, known as reactive chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber (CSM), which contains 35% by weight of chlorine and 1–1.5% by weight of sulfur as sulfonyl chloride (–SO2Cl) units (Figure 1). Recent investigations have shown that cross-linked CSM rubber blends are intended to produce systems that will have physical–mechanical properties superior to those exhibited by each of individual components. 4 –6 Butyl rubber (IIR) is a generic name for a family of isobutylene isoprene copolymers generally containing less than 3% of isoprene groups (Figure 2). IIR is commonly used for inner tubes and air conditioner hoses because of its low gas permeability, good thermal–oxidative stability, and excellent moisture and chemical resistance. 17 Being nonpolar in nature, IIR has poor compatibility with polar elastomers, plastics, and carbon black. Research works are underway to improve the interfacial adhesion of IIR with various materials. Commercially, halogenation of the IIR is carried out in a hydrocarbon medium such as hexane using elemental chlorine or bromine. 18 However, chlorination or bromination usually results in severe corrosion to devices. The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different particle size and different contents (10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 phr) of the nano (primary particle size 15 nm) and micro (primary particle size 28 μm) silica filler on the curing, mechanical, and swelling properties of hybrid materials based on brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene/CSM composites. The chemical interactions of rubber macromolecules with silica filler were investigated by means of the Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) with an attenuated total reflectance (ATR) extension and scanning electron microscope (SEM). Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) study was used for rubber blends miscibility determined.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: All the ingredients were used as received. The rubbers used for composite preparation included brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene (BIIR), bromobutyl 2244 (Exxon Mobil, England; containing 1.08 wt% by weight of bromine), Mooney viscosity, ML (1 + 4) (125°C) 32 ± 5, specific gravity of (ρ) = 0.93 g/cm3; CSM, supplied by Exxon, specific gravity of (ρ) = 1.18 g/cm3, The average molecular weight (Mw) 5.52 × 105 containing 35 wt% by weight of chlorine and 1–1.5% by weight of sulfur as sulfonyl chloride (–SO2Cl) units; active precipitated silica, Ultrasil VN3 (BET 160-200 (N2) m2/g, Dibutyl phthalate (DBP) absorption 220 cm3/100 g, pH 6.7) with primary particle size of 15 nm (nano silica); and diatomaceous earth, Celite 281 (DBP absorption 130 cm 3 /100 g, pH 10) with the average size of primary particles 28 μm (micro silica).

sec.title: Sample preparation and testing
sec.p: Rubber compounds were prepared on a laboratory-size (300 × 600 mm) two-roll mixing mill maintained at 40 ± 5°C. Filled BIIR/CSM (50/50 w/w) rubber compounds were prepared by adding various amounts (10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 phr) of nano and micro silica, and the basic formulation used in the study is given in Table 1.

caption.p: Formulation of brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene/chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber composites reinforced by nano and micro silica

fn.p: DEG: diethylene glycol; MBTS: mercaptobenzothiasole sulfonamide; MgO: magnesium oxide; S: sulfur; ZnO: zinc oxide.

sec.p: The roller speed ratio was n1/n2 = 28/22. 19 The elastomers were separately milled for about 1 min each, keeping a tight nip gap (0.8 mm) and subsequently blended for 3 min. After mixing, different test pieces were cured under 10 MPa pressure at 160°C for 60 min in a Teflon TM-coated mold. The molded samples were taken out only after cooling them to room temperature under pressure by circulating cold water through the platens of the press. The Mooney viscosity (ML (1 + 4)) of the compounds was measured at 100°C with a Mooney viscometer. The sheeted rubber compound was conditioned at 23 ± 2°C for 24 h prior to cure assessment on a Monsanto Moving Die Rheometer (model 100) at 160°C according to American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) D 2705 (Figure 3). The scorch and cure time was calculated based on cure curves. Furthermore, the minimum and maximum torque of the curing curves has been determined. For determination of mechanical properties, all test specimens were compression molded at 160°C during the respective optimum cure time (t c90) determined on the Monsanto rheometer. Tear strength of the composites was tested using an electronic dynamometer according to ASTM D 624 procedure. The abrasion resistance of the samples was tested using an abrader according to ASTM D5963 procedure. The hardness of the composites was measured according to ASTM D2240 using a Shore A type durometer. TS was tested according to ASTM D 412 procedure.

caption.p: Torque (dNm) versus time (minutes) during curing of hybrid materials based on (1) BIIR (C1); (2) CSM (C2); (3) BIIR/CSM (50/50) rubber blends (C3); (4) BIIR/CSM/nano silica (50/50/30 nano silica; C6), and (5) BIIR/CSM/micro silica (50/50/40 micro silica; C12). BIIR: brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene; CSM: chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber.

sec.title: FTIR measurements
sec.p: The infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy with an ATR extension was performed using a Bruker IFS-66 (Bruker Corporation, USA) spectrometer. A minimum of 500 scans was signal averaged at a resolution of 4 cm−1. For FTIR-ATR measurements, the spectrometer was equipped with a liquid nitrogen-cooled mercury cadmium telluride detector. The internal reflection element chosen was a 45° KRS-5 (Thallium Bromo-Iodide). The samples for FTIR-ATR measurements were approximately 0.3 mm thick sheets prepared by compression molding between two Teflon films at 100°C (for the uncross-linked blend). 23

sec.title: DSC measurements
sec.p: The glass transition temperature was determined by DSC (DSC 910, DuPont Instruments).

sec.title: Morphological study using a scanning electron microscope
sec.p: SEM images were obtained using a JEOL 5300 SEM operated at an acceleration voltage of 20 kV and equipped with energy dispersive systems. All the studied samples were coated with a thin layer of gold in a nitrogen atmosphere.

sec.title: Curing characteristics
sec.p: Rheograph of the mixes are given in Figure 3. The minimum torque in the rheograph can be taken as a measure of the viscosity of the masticated rubber. Whenever there is excessive mastication, the viscosity registers a sharp decrease. Normally, the maximum torque in the rheograph can be taken as the maximum viscosity of the rubber compound and is an approximate measure of the cross-link density in the sample.

It is obvious that the minimum torque (R min; Table 2) was slightly increased with the nano silica loading for the hybrid materials based on BIIR/CSM rubber blends, which caused a slight increase in the maximum torque (R max; the cross-link density and chain entanglement are increased). This result is attributed to the fact that the nano silica filler affects the cross-link density by reacting with the chemical ingredients of the formulation, thus leading to a higher torque. The nano silica has larger surface area to interact with the rubber matrix, consequently increasing the torque.

caption.p: Rheological properties of brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene/chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber composites reinforced by nano and micro silica

fn.p: CRI: cure rate index; ML: Mooney viscosity; R min: minimum torque; R max: maximum torque; t s2: scorch time; t c90: optimum cure time.

sec.p: The decrease in cure time is extremely beneficial because it increases the product rate. However, the scorch time is also decreasing. The incorporation of both nano and micro silica in rubber matrix, the scorch time (t s2), and the optimum cure time (t c90) are decreased, while the cure rate index (CRI) is increased. This affects the scorch safety of the compound. It is seen that nano silica-reinforced compounds show a longer scorch time compared with micro silica-reinforced compounds because of the large number of acidic silanol (Si-OH) groups on surface of nano silica compared to micro silica. More hydrogen bonding and interaction with rubber monomers for nano silica is present. 21 Incorporation of the filler into the rubber matrix increased the mixing time, consequently generating more heat due to friction. Moreover, the increasing silica loading increased the compound viscosity, and the generated heat speeded up the cross-linking. 22

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p: The effects of different particle size and loading of silica on TS of hybrid materials based on BIIR/CSM rubber blends are shown in Table 3. It can be seen that both silica showed an increasing trend up to 30 phr for nano silica loading and up to 40 phr for micro silica loading and then decreased with further loading. The increment of TS at lower silica loading was due to better silica–rubber interaction, as the small amounts of fillers make for better dispersion in the rubber matrix. 10 This also explains why at higher silica loading, as silica becomes dominant, the replacement of the silica–rubber interactions by silica–silica interactions led to poorer TSs. 23,24 Meanwhile, at the same silica loading, the nano silica showed higher TS compared to the micro silica. This is because the large surface area of the nano silica provided more contact area between the silica and rubber matrix; hence better adhesion and bonding exists, and there is a positive reinforcement effect.

caption.p: Mechanical properties of brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene/chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber composites reinforced by nano and micro silica

sec.p: The incorporation of filler in a polymer will decrease the elongation at break (Eb) as the presence of filler will reduce the amount of tough material available in the system. 13,14 However, it can be clearly seen that incorporation of nano silica filler in the BIIR/CSM (50/50) rubber composites up to 30 phr improved the breakage mechanisms. This is due to the smaller particles of nano silica (about 15 nm) having good dispersion and better adhesion between the filler and rubber matrix. At the same silica loading, the micro silica-filled hybrid materials showed higher values of Eb, as compared to the nano silica hybrid materials. The nano silica provided more contact area, which helped this filler to disperse well, fix in the rubber chain, and consequently improved the reinforcement between the filler and rubber matrix. The nano silica showed lower Eb values. 14 These two properties, TS and Eb, are also related to the nature and number of cross-links.

Theoretically, increasing the filler in the polymer could significantly enhance the elastic stiffness and increase the modulus. This phenomenon was observed in both figures, where the modulus at 100% and 300% elongation (M100 and M300) increased with increasing silica loading. However, as expected, nano silica showed a higher modulus as compared to micro silica at the same silica loading due to its larger contact area to interact with the rubber matrix. According to previous works, 9,25 the larger surface area can lead to higher levels of stress transferability to the polymer composite because better reinforcement between filler and polymer matrix occurs; hence, the modulus of the composite system increases. Hardness, as an indicator of the material cross-linking degree at the cross-linking temperature, shows a higher value for the hybrid materials based on BIIR/CSM rubber blends reinforced by nano silica than for the ones reinforced by micro silica. This is also supported by the cross-link density (ν) values from the swelling studies (Table 4).

caption.p: Swelling characteristics of brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene/chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber composites reinforced by nano and micro silica

fn.p: E: elastic modulus; M c : molecular weight of the rubber blends between two cross-links; R v: volume of rubber samples; R w: mass of rubber samples; v 2: volume fraction of the sample in the swollen gel; χ: the Flory–Huggins parameter; ν: cross-link density; ρ: density of the composites.

sec.p: Similarly to the modulus, the hardness showed an increasing trend with increasing silica loading, which was expected because with more filler incorporated into the rubber matrix, the flexibility of the rubber chains was reduced, as also observed. 26 Meanwhile, at the same silica loading, the nano silica showed higher hardness values than micro silica. As discussed for the modulus, the hardness properties correlated with the particle size, a larger surface area per volume increased the potential of silica to interact with the rubber matrix and increase the hardness. Tear strength is defined as a force required for obtaining a test piece of cross-linked materials by tearing. By increasing the nano silica content, greater resistance to the tearing force is achieved in comparison to the micro-reinforced composites. Abrasion resistance is defined as the ability of cross-linked material to withstand the progressive removal of the material from its surface, as a result of the mechanical action of rubbing or scraping, or the action of some erosive nature. By silica filler loading, the abrasion loss values are increased, but they are lower for the nano-reinforced hybrid materials. The mechanical properties of the nano-hybrid materials indicate that the silica nanoparticles are stiffening and toughening the rubber matrix.

sec.title: Swelling properties
sec.p: The influence of the filler fraction on the values of the volume rate of swelling (R v), the weight rate of swelling (R w), the volume fraction of the sample in the swollen gel (v 2), the Flory-Huggins parameter (χ), and the elastic modulus (E) obtained by stress–strain measurements. The cross-link density (ν), the molecular weight of the rubber blends between two cross-links (M c), and the rubber composite density (ρr) reinforced by nano and micro silica are given in Table 4.

It is clear that these parameters are increased with the increase in the content of the filler; only the molecular weight between the cross-links (M c) is decreased when the silica is loaded. A higher cross-link density is obtained for nano silica with 30 phr loading and for micro-silica with 40 phr loading; this is the result of the restriction of swelling due to the higher amount of silica particles. This causes an increase in v 2, which in turn increases the cross-link density. The nano silica-reinforced hybrid materials based on BIIR/CSM rubber blends have higher values for the R v, R
w, v 2, E, ν, and χ, but lower values for the M c, compared to the micro-reinforced cross-linked hybrid materials based on BIIR/CSM rubber blends. The swelling studies indicate higher swelling resistance in benzene as a solvent of the hybrid materials based on BIIR/CSM rubber blends containing nano silica than the hybrid materials containing micro silica filler. The swelling of the polymer matrix by solvent depends on diffusivity, as well as solubility of the solvent molecule; which is a rate-dependent process. This is expected, because when the filler is loaded, the amount of the solvent absorbed at equilibrium swelling is smaller for the hybrid materials containing nano silica compared to those containing micro silica. The elastic modulus is the easiest mechanical property to predict, because it is a bulk property, primarily dependant on the strength of the adhesive bond between the matrix and the filler, the filler dispersion, and the amount of particle agglomeration. The elastic modulus obtained by stress–strain measurements is found to increase with the content of the nano silica filler ratio in the BIIR/CSM rubber composites. Figure 4 shows the graph of V ro/V rf versus θ/1 − θ according to Kraus equation.

caption.p: V ro/V rf versus θ/1 − θ according to Kraus equation. V ro: volume fraction rubber in the solvent-unfilled composites; V rf: volume fraction rubber in the filled rubber composites.

sec.p: With the increase in the content of nano and micro silica, the value of V ro/V rf is decreased and higher values are obtained for the micro silica-reinforced hybrid materials than nano silica-reinforced hybrid materials. If the value of V ro/V rf ratio is less than 1, the greater activity of filler can be expected. 24 Reduction in swelling happens near the surface of fillers. This reduction in the swelling of polymers near the surface of filler is explained in two ways: (a) a filler has a catalytic effect on curing process and are expected to have different states of networking, depending on whether the rubber matrix is filled and (b) additional networking is formed between filler surface and polymer matrix. 25 Fillers are classified as (a) filler that has poor adhesion to the surrounding polymer, which is damaging the forces between solvent and polymer (swelling pressure) and (b) the filler that has a strong adhesion to the polymer and which cannot be removed by the solvent molecules. Compared to a higher filler content, polymer swelling is more in smaller filler content. The constant C calculated and determined from equation 11 is 1.11 for nano silica and 1.04 for micro silica hybrid materials, indicating better adhesion between polymer matrix and nano silica.

sec.title: FTIR spectral analysis of nano silica- and micro silica-filled rubber composites
sec.p: FTIR spectroscopy was used to study the nature of the chemical interactions between the BIIR and CSM rubbers, as well as between the BIIR/CSM rubber composites and the silica filler occurring during the mixing of the rubbers with silica. FTIR ATR spectra of hybrid materials with two different silica particle size (nano and micro) contents are displayed in Figure 5. The assignment of the principal bands is presented in Table 5.

caption.p: Some FTIR-ATR spectroscopic data for pure brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene /chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber blend and brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene /chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber composites reinforced by nano and micro silica

fn.p: ν: stretching vibrations, δ: bending vibrations in plain; BIIR: brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene; CSM: chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber; FTIR-ATR: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy-attenuated total reflectance.

caption.p: FTIR-ATR spectra of hybrid materials based on (-) 50/50 BIIR/CSM rubber blend (C3); (….) BIIR/CSM (50/50)/nano silica (C6); and (---)BIIR/CSM(50/50)/micro silica filler (C12). ATR: attenuated total reflectance; BIIR: brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene; CSM: chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber; FTIR: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy.

sec.p: Almost all bands 14 of the pure rubber blend especially those associated with the stretching bands of the CH3–, CH2–, and CH– groups are shifted to lower wave numbers in the filled polymer blend spectra. The bands located at 2927 cm−1, respectively, assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric stretch of the methylene group, are found at 2823 cm−1 for the micro silica-filled hybrid materials based on BIIR/CSM rubber blend and at 2643 cm−1 for the nano silica-filled hybrid materials. The peaks of –S–Cl which is attributed to the –SO2Cl group from CSM and the peak of –C–Br from BIIR rubber are absent in the BIIR/CSM rubber blend spectra. This suggests the cross-linking of the rubber blend macromolecules. The absorption bands at 1433 cm−1 in the cross-linked BIIR/CSM rubber blend are assigned, respectively, to symmetric and asymmetric bending vibration of C=C group. New absorption bands centered at 1072 cm−1 could be assigned to the symmetric stretching modes of SiO–C group from silica filler, and moving symmetric and asymmetric bending vibration of C=C group from 1433 to 1305 cm−1 and 1057 cm−1 for micro and nano silica filled hybrid materials, respectively 27 (Figure 5), suggesting the interaction between polymers matrix with the silica, also.

sec.title: Differential scanning calorimetry
sec.p: DSC scans for the elastomers based on pure rubbers and rubber blends are represented in Figure 6.

caption.p: DSC analysis of hybrid materials based on BIIR (C1), CSM (C2), BIIR/CSM (C3), BIIR/CSM/ nano silica (50/50/30 nano silica) (C6), and BIIR/CSM(50/50)/micro-silica (50/50/40 micro-silica) (C12). BIIR: brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene; CSM: chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber; DSC: differential scanning calorimetry.

sec.p: Possible mechanism of co-cross-linking process between rubbers is presented in Figure 7. T g of the individual rubber macromolecule components in the blend was found to be −39 and −43°C for BIIR and CSM rubbers, respectively. In the BIIR/CSM rubber blend one glass transition temperature was detected (at −39 and −5°C). This is in good agreement with the internal friction results reported by Boonstra. 25 The existence of two T g is one distinctive features related to the presence of partial immiscible blend. On the other hand, it is well known that the distribution of cross-links is not the same even in the partially immiscible cured blend. 26 Therefore, the networks present in each phase of the blend should be different, according to the different curative distribution and cross-links density in both phases. T g of reinforced blends are shifted to −26 and −30°C for nano and micro silica compounds due to the restriction on the segmental motion of the polymeric chain by the addition of cross-linking. 27

caption.p: Co-cross-linking of brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene rubber with chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber.

sec.title: SEM morphology study
sec.p: Figure 8(a) and (b) shows the SEM micrographs of the tensile fracture surfaces filled with nano and micro silica filled hybrid materials based on rubber blends at ×2000 magnification, respectively. The micro silica showed unwetted and bad dispersion than nano silica in the rubber matrix. The nano silica particles were better distributed and have good interaction with the rubber matrix. However, there are other factors that have to be considered in the reinforcement of rubber by filler, such as the volume fraction of filler–filler and filler–matrix compatibility.

caption.p: (a) SEM micrograph of hybrid materials based on BIIR/CSM/nano silica (C6). (b) SEM micrograph of hybrid materials based on BIIR/CSM/micro silica (C12). BIIR: brominated copolymer isobutylene isoprene; CSM: chlorosulfonated polyethylene rubber; SEM: scanning electron microscope.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study investigated the effect of different particle sizes (nano and micro) and different loading of silica on the curing, mechanical, and swelling characteristics of hybrid materials based on BIIR/CSM (50/50) rubber blends. The cure characteristics of hybrid materials based on BIIR/CSM rubber blends with different loadings of nano and micro silica showed that scorch time (t s2) and the optimum cure time (t c90) are decreasing with the increase in silica content. The addition of silica increases the elastic modulus and TS, as well as decreases the Eb. The nano silica hybrid materials showed higher TS, Eb, tensile modulus (M100 and M300), and hardness compared with micro silica hybrid materials. Compared to micro silica, nano silica in small amounts could effectively improve the mechanical properties of the BIIR /CSM rubber hybrid materials. With the increase in silica content, the value of V ro/V rf decreases and higher values for the micro silica than nano silica-reinforced rubber hybrid materials are obtained. The existence of two T g is one distinctive feature related to the presence of partial immiscible between BIIR and CSM rubbers. T g of reinforced blends are shifted to −26 and −30°C for nano and micro silica compounds due to the restriction on the segmental motion of the polymeric chain by the addition of cross-linking. The interactions of rubber macromolecules with the silica filler enable the movement of the absorption infrared bands from RHC=CHR group and (–C–H) links to the lower wave numbers (from 1433 cm−1 to 1305 and 1057 cm−1 for micro and nano silica filler rubber composites, respectively) and confirm the presence of the polymer–filler junctions. The morphology study confirmed that the better dispersion of nano silica improved the adhesion between the silica and the BIIR/CSM (50/50) rubber matrix.
